EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Resource Depot & Smelting Facility at base position (x=-4.5, y=18.5)
Consists of:
• Wooden Chest at (x=-4.5, y=18.5) serving as central storage.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-3.0, y=19.0) for iron smelting.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-4.0, y=21.0) for copper plate production.
• Burner Inserter at (x=0.5, y=21.5) with drop at (x=0.5, y=20.5).

### Automation Lab & Steam Power System (Integrated System) at base configuration
Consists of:
• Lab at (x=-7.5, y=18.5) dedicated to automation research.
• Electricity Groups (including original poles and later additions) at (x=3.5, y=22.5) and (x=-4.5, y=17.5).
• Steam Engines positioned at (x=-13.5, y=16.5) (primary) and additional engines at (x=-14.5, y=13.5), (x=7.5, y=35.5), and (x=8.5, y=20.5).
• A Fluid System Submodule (Boiler Module) comprising several Boiler + Steam Engine pairs and PipeGroup connections, with noted connection issues and segmented pipe group remnants.

### Copper Cable Factory at position (x=1.5, y=19.5)
Consists of:
• Assembling Machine at (x=1.5, y=19.5) reconfigured for iron gear-wheel production.
  – (Update: Recently supplied with 2 iron plates; however, it remains unpowered due to unresolved power connectivity.)
• Burner Inserter at (x=1.5, y=17.5).
• Input Chest at (x=2.5, y=17.5).
• Output Chest at (x=1.5, y=21.5).
• Dedicated Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-5.5, y=21.5).
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=0.5, y=17.5).
• Additional Burner Inserters at (x=2.5, y=16.5) and (x=3.5, y=17.5).

### Copper Extraction System (adjacent to the copper smelting furnace)
Consists of:
• An Extraction Burner Inserter (with pickup and drop at positions centered around x≈–3.5, y≈23.5),
• Buffer and Chest arrangements for copper ore handling.

### Extraction Belt Depot at position (x=3.5, y=15.5)
Consists of:
• Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5) acting as the belt depot.
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=4.5, y=15.5) for copper plate conveyance.
• Depot Burner Inserter managing pick‐up and drop positions.

### Belt Connection Target Setup for Copper Extraction
Consists of:
• The extraction source (Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5)),
• An Extraction Inserter at (x=4.5, y=15.5) feeding into a manual Transport Belt Chain spanning multiple segments,
• A New Target Inserter at (x=8.5, y=9.5) to guide the belt chain.

### Remote Fluid Integration System at remote region (approximate center: x=-30, y=40)
Consists of:
• Offshore Pump at (x=-30.5, y=37.5) (WORKING).
• Boiler for fluid heating at (x=-29.0, y=33.5).
• A PipeGroup connection carrying water (status FULL_OUTPUT) with unresolved segmented connections aimed at linking to a New Boiler near (x=-10.0, y=22.5).

### Expanded Smelting Zone
Consists of:
• Stone Furnaces placed at (x=-20.0, y=22.0), (x=-20.0, y=25.0), and (x=-17.0, y=25.0).
• One intended furnace at (x=-17.0, y=22.0) that could not be placed due to a blocking PipeGroup at (x=-17.5, y=21.5).
• A successfully placed Stone Furnace at (x=0.0, y=26.0) dedicated to copper smelting.

### New Network Structures
• Long-distance Transport Belt Network spanning from (x=-3.5, y=10.5) to (x=22.5, y=10.5) (29 belts) for interzone material transfer.
• Copper Ore Transport Line (region x≈8–9, y≈11–15) comprising 6 belts carrying copper ore.
• Integrated Auxiliary Transport Network centered at (x≈3, y≈16) with connected Belt Groups (23 belts and 16 belts) for localized production supply.
• Short Belt Connector A (approximate location x≈-0.5 to -1.5, y≈20.5) linking adjacent factory sections via 2 belts.
• Short Belt Connector B (around x≈-4.5 to -5.5 with nearby segments) enhancing local connectivity via 2 belts plus additional segments.

All other structures remain unchanged from previous reports.

────────────────────────
ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────
• Inventory and Crafting:
 – Verify that required items exist in inventory prior to initiating placement actions to prevent delays.
 – Ensure that production units have the necessary input materials before starting processing.

• Fuel and Operational Readiness:
 – Monitor and replenish fuel for burner inserters, furnaces, and boilers; persistent low-fuel warnings can stall operations.
 – Confirm that all fuel-based devices are adequately supplied to maintain continuous operation.

• Placement Validation:
 – Confirm that target locations are unobstructed and fall within the designated buildable area.
 – When placing power infrastructure (e.g. Small Electric Poles), ensure the intended location is within the maximum placement distance. Repeated errors—such as “Unable to place Small Electric Pole” and “target position is too far away” (target at (0.0, 23.0) versus a maximum distance of 10)—indicate the need to move closer to the desired location.
 – Evaluate adjacent placement possibilities relative to existing structures; if directions (LEFT, UP, DOWN) consistently fail, reassess the buildable area constraints.

• Power Network Connectivity:
 – Ensure structures that require electricity (such as the Assembling Machine in the Copper Cable Factory) are connected to a functional grid. Persistent warnings like “not receiving electricity” suggest that power poles must be repositioned within an acceptable range.
 – Address spatial constraints and obstacles that may impede proper pole placement to improve setup connectivity.

• Fluid and Pipe Network Integrity:
 – Validate that all PipeGroup connections are complete and free from segmentation issues, ensuring proper fluid flow.
 – Verify alignment and connectivity between adjacent pipe segments and boilers to prevent isolated or unconnected sections.

(No agent-defined functions were identified; hence no NAMESPACE section is provided.)
